case_body_condition: Not recognizable - Partial remains with soft tissues
case_circumstances:
On 22 March 2000, an employee of the Waste Management Trash Recycling Plant, located at 1635 W. Medill Avenue, Chicago, Illinois, discovered a human leg protruding from a black plastic trash bag. 
An extensive search of more than 300 tons of garbage revealed no additional remains.

Upon subsequent examination it was revealed that the bag contained a right thigh and a right lower leg with foot attached.  

The leg had been amputated from the hip and the tissue surrounding the knee was severed and the knee bone dislocated from the leg bone. The amputation wounds appeared very neat with no signs of sawing or secondary incisions.

There were ligature marks present on both sections of leg and a brownish colored polypropylene twine apparently used as tourniquets is still present.

A small amount of red nail polish was present on one of the toes.

Post mortem examination revealed the following:
Thigh is 18.6 inches long, weighing 8.2 pounds.
Along the proximal cut surface of the thigh, there are several shallow cutaneous incisions that are consistent with initial unsuccessful cutting attempts.

On the lateral and posterior aspect of the thigh, there are multiple scattered contusions which are deep, involving the entire thickness of the subcutaneous fat tissue which measure in size from 0.7 to 2.0 inches.

On the anterior and lateral aspect of the thigh there are multiple linear abrasions, which range in length from 0.5 to 3.0 inches.

On the posterior and lateral aspect of the leg, there are multiple linear abrasions, which range in length from 0.3 to 4.o inches.

On the anterolateral and proximal aspect of the leg there is an incised wound, 0.6 inches long and 0.3 to 0.4 niches deep.

On the anterior aspect of the leg there are three oval to irregular purple/blue contusions which range in size from 1 inch in greatest dimension to 4.0 x 2.0 inches. The underlying fat tissue demonstrates extensive hemorrhage through the entire thickness.

The foot is 9.6 inches long, the toenails are short and clean and on the first toenail, there is 0.1 inch residual pink/red nail polish,

 There is no evidence of post mortem decomposition changes in either muscle or skin.

A sample was extracted  from the bone and submitted for DNA analysis. It is presently on file with the FBI.

Tissue sample tested positive for, Benzoylecgonine, ethanol, and cocaine.

Anthropologic examination performed by Dr. Clyde Snow, assumes the leg and thigh were that of a female black between the ages of 18 and 45. Although his examination could not totally discount that the leg originated from a woman of Hispanic origin.

His findings suggest that dismemberment was carried out very skillfully with a fine bladed instrument by a person with some basic anatomical knowledge.

ViCAP Case Number 2012CPD00003.
Update on 26 JUNE 2012 by Det. Czworniak
A duplicate entry listed under 10349, has been deleted.
fingerprints: Fingerprint information is currently not available
case_clothing_with_body: One brown colored high heel womans left shoe size 7B, was recovered near by. DNA testing was inconclusive if this shoe was from this Victim.
dental: Dental information / charting is currently not available
documents: There are currently no documents available for this case.
